resources.string: Five Albums That Changed My Life

I Am a Bird Now is a striking portrait of transgender issues in our society. Touching on the themes of love, death, mental health and family, I Am a Bird Now is an illuminating journey into the perspective of Antony Hegarty. Antony\'s rich, vibrating voice adds intensity with each passing song and her messages ring soundly, even ten years after the album\'s release.

Increased crime rates notwithstanding, there\'s something unsettling about living in the inner city. The ambient noises of populated areas can cause unease and Burial taps into that feeling with his use of sampling to create a musical environment like nothing I had heard before. Clips of footsteps, car noises, and what sounds like empty bullets hitting the ground litter the album like trash on the street. Burial\'s technique is an inspiration that I draw from when creating music, and Untrue\'s raw percussion style is something I emulate in my works.

This record is everything I wanted to be when I grew up. I was exposed to Cake as a pre-teen and I was immediately drawn in by its stylish sarcasm. I listened and learned from the criticisms of rock culture, classism and religion. I turned a critical eye towards the excesses of drug and alcohol abuse, but also toward the establishment that warned me of the dangers therein. Motorcade of Generosity is a record that just hates everything and loves every minute of it.

In contrast to Motorcade, Hurry Up, We\'re Dreaming is everything I remembered about childhood once I had grown up. The sense of wonder and imagination is vivid across the entire double album. The synths shine and shimmer, but they retain an aura of nostalgia for simpler times, like finding your favorite toy in an attic. The pleasant soundscapes peppered throughout the anthems on the record are welcoming and warm. Hurry Up reminds me to be playful and childlike in my creativity and to explore every possible nook and cranny of my imagination.

For the longest time, I would get annoyed if I could hear words but not understand what the words were saying. It wasn\'t until I heard Heaven or Las Vegas that I discovered the joy of appreciating the tone of language on its own. While the guitars drenched in reverb, chorus and countless other effects soar through their perfectly crafted songs, just-audible lyrics pop up through the mix, and they\'ll trick you into thinking you understand a single word they\'re saying. Between the thick Scottish accent and the way the lyrics settle behind the instruments, Cocteau Twins have seemingly crafted a language of their own.
Album cover for I Am a Bird Now by Antony and the Johnsons
Album cover for Untrue by Burial
Album cover for Motorcade of Generosity by Cake
Album cover for Hurry Up, We\'re Dreaming by M83
Album cover for Heaven Or Las Vegas by Cocteau Twins
